title: What is the difference between Religion and Science in the pursuit of spiritual powers?
first_phrase: In the previous text, the author touched on the subject of the difference between Religion and Science in the pursuit of spiritual power. In this last part, the author elaborates on the concept of Absolute Truth and its relationship with different religions like Caldeismo, Buddismo, and Cattolicesimo. The author emphasizes that the difference lies in the method of participation in the Universal Truth and not in the substance of conceiving it. The Caldeismo considers everything as alive and intelligent individuals, while the Buddismo focuses on individualization towards the highest principle. On the other hand, the Cattolicesimo seeks to synthesize Vital Truth in its concept of universality. The text explains how these three religions relate to the concept of the Universal Life and how they make those who practice them feel connected to the world around them.
content: Da ciò' scaturisce chiaramente che la differenza e' nella partecipazione come metodo alla Verità' Unica e non nella sostanza di concepire l'Unita' Universale. Infatti il considerare tutte le cose, quelle che visibilmente paiono inanimate, con vite e intelligenze, come coscienze' e virtù' (calderismo) rende colui che così' vede il mondo Universo partecipe alla Vita di tutte le cose in natura. La forma esteriore o il seme o la coscienza interiore di tutto ciò' che e', e' manifestazione della vita unitaria universale e chi in tal modo considera la natura delle cose visibili ed invisibili non può' non sentirsi con coscienza chiara o scura, partecipante alla vita universale che vede e sente svolgersi sotto i suoi sensi fisici. Ma l'altra faccia del cubo, sintetica ed individualista, sprigiona un sentimento di concentrazione unitaria in tutta l'essenza intellettiva del santo o del Budda o del Religioso.
last_phrase: In conclusion, the participation method towards the ultimate Truth is the key difference between various religious practices, rather than the substance of the Universal Unity. Seeing all things, even inanimate objects, as conscious beings with virtues, makes one feel connected and participative in the universal life. However, the synthetic and individualistic aspect of religion also leads to a concentration of intellectual essence towards a transcendent beatitude. The law of Karma, as demonstrated in Buddhism, represents the transformation of will towards special existence that all beings prepare for themselves. Christianity seeks to find the maximum common ground of intellectual life as a Universal Karmic Creation. Understanding these various aspects under the light of initiatic wisdom can help us study the diverse approaches to the Great Work from a collective, profane, and religious perspective.
